problem_statement.description:
One hot summer day Pete and his friend Billy decided to buy a watermelon. They chose the biggest and the ripest one, in their opinion. After that the watermelon was weighed, and the scales showed w kilos. They rushed home, dying of thirst, and decided to divide the berry, however they faced a hard problem.

Pete and Billy are great fans of even numbers, that's why they want to divide the watermelon in such a way that each of the two parts weighs even number of kilos, at the same time it is not obligatory that the parts are equal. The boys are extremely tired and want to start their meal as soon as possible, that's why you should help them and find out, if they can divide the watermelon in the way they want. For sure, each of them should get a part of positive weight.
problem_statement.input_specification: The first (and the only) input line contains integer number w (1 ≤ w ≤ 100) — the weight of the watermelon bought by the boys.
problem_statement.output_specification: Print YES, if the boys can divide the watermelon into two parts, each of them weighing even number of kilos; and NO in the opposite case.

examples.note: For example, the boys can divide the watermelon into two parts of 2 and 6 kilos respectively (another variant — two parts of 4 and 4 kilos).

examples.title: Sample case from problem statement
examples.why_included: This is the example provided in the problem statement to verify basic understanding and a standard 'YES' case.

examples.title: Minimum input value
examples.why_included: Tests the smallest possible input (w=1) according to the constraints. It's odd, so it must be 'NO'.

examples.title: Critical edge case with weight 2
examples.why_included: This is the most important edge case. While 2 is even, it cannot be split into two positive even integers (only 1+1).

examples.title: Smallest possible 'YES' case
examples.why_included: Tests the smallest weight (w=4) that can be split into two positive even integers (2+2).

examples.title: Maximum input value
examples.why_included: Tests the largest possible input (w=100) according to constraints. It is an even number greater than 2.

examples.title: Maximum odd input value
examples.why_included: Tests the largest odd number within the constraints. Any odd number should result in 'NO'.

examples.title: Smallest odd number greater than 1
examples.why_included: Tests a small odd number to confirm the parity check logic.

examples.title: Small even number greater than 4
examples.why_included: A standard 'YES' case (can be split into 2+4) that is not a power of two.

examples.title: Small odd prime number
examples.why_included: Tests a prime number. The core logic is about parity, not primality, but this case helps eliminate incorrect assumptions.

examples.title: A larger odd prime number
examples.why_included: Another test with a prime number to reinforce that the logic depends solely on parity.

examples.why_included: Tests a large even number close to the maximum constraint.

examples.title: An even number not divisible by 4
examples.why_included: Tests an even number not divisible by 4 (e.g., 2+8, 4+6), confirming that divisibility by 4 is not required.
